title: American_Top_40_1978_December_16th
description:
"From Boston to Biloxi; from Bangor to Barstow, These are the biggest hits in America. At number 21, here's Bob Seger and The Silver Bullet Band with, 'We've Got Tonight'."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this countdown:

There is a hit by the most successful studio musician turned singer of all time. This man previously recorded for Elvis Presley, The Mamas and the Pappas, Rick Nelson, The Association, Herb Alpert, Frank Sinatra, The Beach Boys, Johnny Cash, and many others.

Casey spotlights the only song by Elton John, in his eight-year career, never even to make the hot 100, but it still sold a million copies.

Casey tells about the latest tour by a band with a stage production which includes 60 tons of equipment, 48 roadies, 7 tractor-trailers, and a stage prop 50 feet in diameter, standing two stories tall, which begins to roar and smoke before lifting off the stage at the beginning of the show (and they're in this countdown with a double-sided hit!).

Casey plays an extra by a group who got their start singing Christmas carols in the back of an old Rambler station-wagon. As of 1978, they were the biggest selling American group in chart history.

A listener wants to know which instrumentalist leads in having the most (instrumental) top 40 albums. From 1952 to 1972, this man had 33 top 40 albums.

Casey plays the biggest selling single of all time, which appeared on the pop chart every year around the holidays from 1942 through 1951, and then again from 1954 through 1962!

For the number one song, Casey plays the fake duet by Neil Diamond and Barbra Streisand which was first artificially put together by a broadcaster and inspired the actual hit.
